top_comment.text:
Perhaps we're looking at this the wrong way. We're judging this sentence 
relative to other sentences, when we really should be asking: is this 
sentence fair on its own?

Look, it's easy to scream "ELECTRIC CHAIR!" when you look at what other 
murderers have been punished with in Texas-- it's harder to realize that 
excessive punishment might not necessarily be the best solution. Throwing 
the kid in jail for 20 years will just make him a career criminal. On the 
other hand, rehabilitation is generally much cheaper and more effective.

As a society we have to believe in second chances, even if the mistake was 
murder. Sure, punish people, but don't do it because you're vindictive-- do 
it because you want the criminal to return to normal society one day.

Put yourself in this kid's shoes and try to realize how a 20 year prison 
sentence would utterly destroy your life.﻿

I think I really have to play devil's advocate here, I think people are 
just being a little harsh on the judge

1) Whether the victims were good samaritans or not are irrelevant, the 
killing was accidental
2) Much has been made of the "affluenza" argument, well honestly you have 
no idea, if that was the deciding factor, for all anyone knows, that held 
no sway with the judge whatsoever, & the judge made a decision that the kid 
was  repentant, or was likely to reform,  Perhaps the judge might simply 
have made a pragmatic decision that it was better for the tax payers if the 
parents paid for 10 years of rehab instead of the state paying for 10 years 
of prison, not fair perhaps, but better for everyone in the long run, and 
10 years in rehab away from family is no getting away scott free, now is 
that fair? Maybe not, but then it isn't fair that this kid probably grew up 
in a mansion, & you or I did not, that is just how money works
3)Much has been made about how the black kid was treated more harshly for a 
lower body count,, well that's not how the law works, the records are 
sealed, and you know nothing of the details of the other case, perhaps the 
other kid had a long history of violence, or the attack was particularly 
premeditated or violent, or perhaps the kid was completely unrepentant at 
trial,many factors could have affected the outcome of that trial
4)Again the laws does not necessarily look at consequences, but at 
intention, that's why attempted murder is a crime, and killing in self 
defence is not, similarly drunk driving, while grossly negligent is not a 
malicious act, beating someone up is, 
5)Again, the affluenza argument was unfortunate, but then again, he was a 
16 year old kid, just because his parents were wealthy, doesn't mean that 
his parents were good parents, the responsibility argument may have been a 
vaild defence, completely separate from the "affluenza"
6)The most perfunctory of arguments, Jailing this kid won't bring the other 
4 people back﻿

In double-blind tests wine tasters are about as proficient in 
distinguishing expensive from cheap wine as a coin toss. There is no actual 
factor that would necessitate the price of a bottle of fermented grape 
juice to be over 15 USD. Expensive wines do not taste better.

gamble, a game of chance. You cannot (or don't want to) think of wealth in

objective reality of obtaining wealth seems to be obscured to you.
